references.B75MOU01NAUS: Mount, R. H. 1975. The Reptiles and Amphibians of Alabama. Auburn University Agricultural Experiment Station, Auburn, Alabama. vii + 347 pp.
references.B83DEG01NAUS: DeGraaf, R. M., and D. D. Rudis. 1983. Amphibians and reptiles of New England. Habitats and natural history. Univ. Massachusetts Press. vii + 83 pp.
references.B70FIT01NAUS: Fitch, H. S. 1970. Reproductive cycles of lizards and snakes. Univ. Kansas Museum Natural History Miscellaneous Publication 52:1-247.
references.B81VOG01NAUS: Vogt, R. G. 1981. Natural history of amphibians and reptiles of Wisconsin. Milwaukee Public Museum. 205 pp.
references.A63FIT02NAUS: Fitch, H. S. 1963. Natural history of the black rat snake (ELAPHE O. OBSOLETA) in Kansas. Copeia 1963:649-658.
references.A00MUL01USGP: Mullin, S. J., W.H.N. Gutzke, G. D. Zenitsky, and R. J. Cooper. 2000. Home ranges of rat snakes (Colubridae: ELAPHE) in different habitats. Herpetological Review 31:20-22.
references.B01HUL01USGP: Hulse, A.C., C.J. McCoy, and E.J. Censky. 2001. Amphibians and Reptiles of Pennsylvania and the Northeast.  Cornell University Press.  419 pp.
references.B00JOH02USGP: Johnson, T. R. 2000. The amphibians and reptiles of Missouri. Second edition. Missouri Department of Conservation, Jefferson City. 400 pp.
references.A82KIL02NAUS: Kilpatrick, C.W. and M.A. Romano. 1982. ELAPHE OBSOLETA OBSOLETA (BLACK RAT SNAKE). HEPETOL. REV. 13(1):25.
references.B84TEN01NAUS: Tennant, A. 1984. The Snakes of Texas. Texas Monthly Press, Austin, Texas. 561 pp.
references.B87GRE01NAUS: Green, N. B., and T. K. Pauley. 1987. Amphibians and reptiles in West Virginia. University of Pittsburg Press, Pittsburg, Pennsylvania. xi + 241 pp.
references.B82COL01NAUS: Collins, J. T. 1982. Amphibians and reptiles in Kansas. Second edition. Univ. Kansas Mus. Nat. Hist., Pub. Ed. Ser. 8. xiii + 356 pp.
references.A85WEA01NAUS: Weatherhead, P. J., and M. B. Charland. 1985. Habitat selection in an Ontario population of the snake, ELAPHE OBSOLETA. J. Herpetol. 19:12-19.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
references.B72MIN01NAUS: Minton, S. A., Jr. 1972. Amphibians and reptiles of Indiana. Indiana Academy Science Monographs 3. v + 346 pp.
references.A01BLO01SEGP: Blouin-Demers, and G. Weatherhead, P.J., 2001 Habitat use by black rat snakes (Elaphe obsoleta obsoleta) in fragmented forests. Ecology. v. 82 (10) p. 2882-2896.
references.A89WEA02NAUS: Weatherhead, P. J., and D. J. Hoysak. 1989. Spatial and activity patterns of black rat snakes (ELAPHE OBSOLETA) from radiotelemetry and recapture data. Can. J. Zool. 67:463-468.
references.W12NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
references.B98TEN01USGP: Tennant, A. 1998. A field guide to Texas snakes. Second edition. Gulf Publishing Company, Houston, Texas.
references.A96PRI01NAUS: Prior, K. A., and P. J. Weatherhead. 1996. Habitat features of black rat snake hibernacula in Ontario. Journal of Herpetology 30:211-218.
references.A01BUR01USGP: Burbrink, F. T. 2001. Systematics of the eastern ratsnake complex (Elaphe obsoleta). Herpetological Monographs 15:1-53.

habitat_description:
The eastern snake occurs from New England to southern Florida. Populations can be found east of the Appalachian Mountains, east of the Apalachicola River in Florida, and also east of the Chattahoochee River in Georgia. Records for this species regarding its western distribution within its range are limited (Burbrink 2001). This species is presumably a ratsnake that has been introduced to the Bahamas, but precise identification of such species remains uncertain (Natureserve.org).

This is a snake that burrows in or using soil, leaf litter, tree logs, hollow trees, and standing snag. This species is known to burrow or to use deep crevices during hibernation. This species inhabits conifer woodland, savanna, hardwood forest, bare rock, cliffs, cropland, hedgerow, and various suburban settings. Its preferred habitats are characterized by wooded canyons, rocky timbered upland, wooded areas of streams and rivers, old fields, swamps, barnyards, and rural/suburban buildings. Reports include observations in areas comprised of open areas adjacent to wooded areas.

NE	-Woodland, savanna, hardwood forest, bare rock, cliffs, cropland, hedgerow, and various suburban settings.

SE	-Wooded canyons, rocky timbered upland, wooded areas of streams and rivers, old fields, swamps, barnyards, and rural/suburban buildings.
